mainTopic.title: Oral Cavity and Salivary Glands
mainTopic.content_info: While the lectures are good for getting an idea of the structure of the course, the slides mostly contain images and diagrams, so to get more detailed information it is best to look through the lecture handouts, which follow the structure of the lecture only with more detailed descripitions, and the student notes which are not only more detailed but cover more topics than the lectures.

quizzes.question: In the oral cavity, certain regions are lined by mucosa adapted to withstand significant mechanical stress during mastication. Identify the specific type of oral mucosa and its defining epithelial characteristic that enables it to resist abrasion in areas like the hard palate and gingiva.
quizzes.goodAnswer: Masticatory mucosa, characterized by a keratinized stratified squamous epithelium, is specifically located in areas such as the hard palate and gingiva, providing robust protection against mechanical forces during chewing.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Lining mucosa, characterized by a parakeratinized stratified squamous epithelium, is specifically located in areas such as the hard palate and gingiva, designed for flexibility and distension rather than primary abrasion resistance.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Specialized mucosa, characterized by a non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium, is specifically located in areas such as the hard palate and gingiva, primarily involved in sensory functions and taste perception, not mechanical protection.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Masticatory mucosa, characterized by a non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium with rete ridges, is specifically located in areas such as the hard palate and gingiva, designed to facilitate absorption and secretion under mechanical stress.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Lining mucosa, characterized by a keratinized simple squamous epithelium, is specifically located in areas such as the hard palate and gingiva, providing a thin barrier for rapid diffusion and minimal mechanical resistance.

quizzes.question: Regions of the oral cavity that require flexibility and distensibility, such as the soft palate, cheeks, and the floor of the mouth, are lined by a specific type of mucosa. Determine the type of oral mucosa and its key epithelial feature that allows for movement and expansion in these areas.
quizzes.goodAnswer: Lining mucosa, distinguished by its non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium, is found in the soft palate, cheeks, and floor of the mouth, providing the necessary elasticity and movement for these oral structures.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Masticatory mucosa, distinguished by its non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium with long papillae, is found in the soft palate, cheeks, and floor of the mouth, designed for high resistance to shear forces and friction.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Specialized mucosa, distinguished by its keratinized stratified columnar epithelium, is found in the soft palate, cheeks, and floor of the mouth, primarily involved in taste perception and protection from chemical irritants.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Lining mucosa, distinguished by its orthokeratinized stratified squamous epithelium, is found in the soft palate, cheeks, and floor of the mouth, providing a rigid and protective layer against mechanical abrasion.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Masticatory mucosa, distinguished by its parakeratinized pseudostratified columnar epithelium, is found in the soft palate, cheeks, and floor of the mouth, providing both flexibility and significant resistance to mechanical stress.

quizzes.question: The dorsal surface of the tongue, a specialized region within the oral cavity, is responsible for gustatory sensation. Identify the type of oral mucosa present in this region and its defining characteristic related to taste perception.
quizzes.goodAnswer: Specialized mucosa, characterized by the presence of taste buds within its keratinized stratified squamous epithelium and lingual papillae, is located on the dorsal tongue surface, playing a critical role in the sense of taste.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Masticatory mucosa, characterized by the presence of taste buds within its non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium and filiform papillae, is located on the dorsal tongue surface, primarily involved in mechanical manipulation of food.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Lining mucosa, characterized by the presence of taste buds within its pseudostratified columnar epithelium and fungiform papillae, is located on the dorsal tongue surface, providing flexibility and movement for taste perception.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Specialized mucosa, characterized by the absence of taste buds but presence of goblet cells within its keratinized stratified squamous epithelium and foliate papillae, is located on the dorsal tongue surface, playing a minor role in gustatory sensation.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Masticatory mucosa, characterized by the absence of taste buds but presence of Merkel cells within its non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium and circumvallate papillae, is located on the dorsal tongue surface, primarily involved in tactile sensation and pressure detection.

quizzes.question: Enamel, renowned as the hardest biological tissue in the human body, owes its exceptional properties to its mineral composition and structural arrangement. Describe the primary mineral component of enamel and the organization of its structural units that contribute to its hardness and acid resistance.
quizzes.goodAnswer: Enamel is primarily composed of hydroxyapatite crystals, arranged in densely packed enamel rods (prisms) that are oriented perpendicular to the enamel surface, providing remarkable hardness and resistance to acid dissolution during mastication.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Enamel is primarily composed of fluorapatite crystals, arranged in loosely packed enamel rods (prisms) that are oriented parallel to the enamel surface, providing moderate hardness and susceptibility to acid dissolution.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Dentin is primarily composed of hydroxyapatite crystals, arranged in loosely packed dentinal tubules that are oriented perpendicular to the dentin surface, providing exceptional hardness and resistance to thermal changes and mechanical stress.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Enamel is primarily composed of carbonated apatite crystals, arranged in interwoven enamel rods (prisms) that are oriented obliquely to the enamel surface, providing flexibility and resilience against occlusal forces but limited acid resistance.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Cementum is primarily composed of hydroxyapatite crystals, arranged in sparsely distributed cementocytes within a collagen matrix that are oriented randomly across the root surface, providing attachment for periodontal ligaments and limited hardness.

quizzes.question: Dentin, forming the bulk of the tooth structure, is a vital tissue synthesized by specialized cells. Identify the cellular component responsible for dentinogenesis, describe their location within the tooth, and outline the process of dentin matrix formation and subsequent mineralization.
quizzes.goodAnswer: Odontoblasts, located at the pulpal border of dentin, are responsible for dentin formation. They secrete predentin, an organic matrix which then undergoes mineralization to become mature dentin through a process of appositional growth, layer by layer.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Ameloblasts, located at the enamel-dentin junction, are responsible for dentin formation. They secrete predentin, a mineralized matrix which then undergoes demineralization to become mature dentin through a process of interstitial growth, expanding from within.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Cementoblasts, located on the outer surface of cementum, are responsible for dentin formation. They secrete predentin, a cellular matrix which then undergoes calcification to become mature dentin through a process of circumferential growth, adding layers around the periphery.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Odontoclasts, located within the pulp chamber, are responsible for dentin formation. They secrete predentin, an inorganic matrix which then undergoes hydration to become mature dentin through a process of resorption and redeposition.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Fibroblasts, located throughout the periodontal ligament, are responsible for dentin formation. They secrete predentin, a fibrous matrix which then undergoes ossification to become mature dentin through a process of intramembranous ossification, converting connective tissue directly into bone-like tissue.

quizzes.question: Cementum, the outer covering of the tooth root, plays a crucial role in anchoring the tooth within the alveolar bone. Describe the structural composition of cementum and its primary function in maintaining tooth stability and periodontal health.
quizzes.goodAnswer: Cementum is a mineralized connective tissue covering the tooth root, primarily composed of hydroxyapatite crystals and collagen fibers, serving as the attachment medium for periodontal ligament fibers, which are essential for tooth anchorage in the alveolar bone and stress distribution.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Enamel is a non-mineralized epithelial tissue covering the tooth root, primarily composed of amelogenin proteins and water, serving as the attachment medium for gingival fibers, which are essential for tooth anchorage in the alveolar bone and nutrient supply.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Dentin is a partially mineralized mesenchymal tissue covering the tooth root, primarily composed of apatite crystals and elastin fibers, serving as the attachment medium for Sharpey's fibers, which are essential for tooth anchorage in the alveolar bone and shock absorption.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Cementum is an acellular bone tissue covering the tooth crown, primarily composed of calcium phosphate and glycosaminoglycans, serving as the attachment medium for alveolar bone proper, which is essential for tooth anchorage and occlusal stability.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Pulp is a vascularized soft tissue covering the tooth root, primarily composed of fibroblasts and ground substance, serving as the attachment medium for cementoblasts, which are essential for tooth anchorage and sensory innervation of the tooth.

quizzes.question: Salivary glands are composed of different types of secretory units that produce saliva with varying characteristics. Differentiate between serous and mucous acini based on their cellular morphology, the nature of their secretory products, and their staining properties observed under histological examination.
quizzes.goodAnswer: Serous acini are characterized by pyramidal-shaped cells with spherical nuclei and apical zymogen granules, producing a watery, enzyme-rich secretion that stains intensely with eosin, while mucous acini have columnar cells with flattened basal nuclei and mucin droplets, producing a viscous secretion that stains palely with eosin.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Mucous acini are characterized by cuboidal-shaped cells with apical nuclei and basal zymogen granules, producing a watery, enzyme-poor secretion that stains intensely with hematoxylin, while serous acini have squamous cells with central nuclei and mucin droplets, producing a viscous secretion that stains palely with hematoxylin.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Serous acini are characterized by columnar-shaped cells with flattened basal nuclei and mucin droplets, producing a viscous, enzyme-rich secretion that stains palely with eosin, while mucous acini have pyramidal cells with spherical nuclei and apical zymogen granules, producing a watery secretion that stains intensely with eosin.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Both serous and mucous acini are characterized by pyramidal cells with spherical nuclei and apical mucin droplets, but serous acini produce a viscous secretion rich in enzymes and stain darkly with hematoxylin, whereas mucous acini produce a watery secretion poor in enzymes and stain palely with hematoxylin.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Both serous and mucous acini are characterized by columnar cells with flattened basal nuclei and basal zymogen granules, but serous acini produce a watery secretion rich in mucin and stain palely with eosin, whereas mucous acini produce a viscous secretion poor in mucin and stain darkly with eosin.

quizzes.question: The ductal system of salivary glands plays a critical role in modifying the primary saliva secreted by acini. Describe the structural features and functional roles of intercalated ducts, including their epithelial lining, their contribution to saliva composition, and their spatial relationship to striated ducts.
quizzes.goodAnswer: Intercalated ducts, lined by a simple cuboidal epithelium, are located proximally to acini and contribute to saliva modification by secreting bicarbonate ions and absorbing chloride ions, thereby initiating electrolyte adjustment and connecting acini directly to the striated ducts distally.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Striated ducts, lined by a pseudostratified columnar epithelium, are located proximally to acini and contribute to saliva modification by secreting sodium ions and absorbing potassium ions, thereby regulating osmotic balance and connecting acini indirectly to the intercalated ducts distally.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Intercalated ducts, lined by a simple squamous epithelium, are located distally to acini and contribute to saliva modification by secreting potassium ions and absorbing sodium ions, thereby finalizing electrolyte concentration and connecting acini directly to the excretory ducts proximally.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Interlobular ducts, lined by a stratified cuboidal epithelium, are located proximally to acini and contribute to saliva modification by secreting hydrogen ions and absorbing bicarbonate ions, thereby adjusting pH levels and connecting acini indirectly to the intercalated ducts proximally.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Excretory ducts, lined by a transitional epithelium, are located distally to acini and contribute to saliva modification by secreting chloride ions and absorbing bicarbonate ions, thereby concentrating enzymes and connecting acini directly to the main salivary duct.

quizzes.question: Striated ducts are essential components of salivary glands responsible for the final modification of saliva before it is released into the oral cavity. Explain the function of striated ducts, emphasizing their unique epithelial cell characteristics, their specific role in electrolyte transport, and the resulting effect on saliva tonicity.
quizzes.goodAnswer: Striated ducts are lined by simple columnar epithelium characterized by basal striations due to infoldings of the basal plasma membrane and numerous mitochondria, actively modifying saliva by reabsorbing sodium and chloride ions and secreting potassium and bicarbonate ions, resulting in hypotonic saliva compared to plasma.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Intercalated ducts are lined by pseudostratified epithelium characterized by apical striations due to cilia and microvilli, passively modifying saliva by reabsorbing potassium and bicarbonate ions and secreting sodium and chloride ions, resulting in hypertonic saliva compared to plasma.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Striated ducts are lined by stratified squamous epithelium characterized by apical striations due to keratin filaments, actively modifying saliva by reabsorbing water and glucose and secreting proteins and lipids, resulting in isotonic saliva compared to plasma.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Excretory ducts are lined by transitional epithelium characterized by basal striations due to desmosomes and hemidesmosomes, passively modifying saliva by reabsorbing bicarbonate and hydrogen ions and secreting phosphate and calcium ions, resulting in hypertonic saliva compared to plasma.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Striated ducts are lined by simple squamous epithelium characterized by apical striations due to tight junctions and adherens junctions, actively modifying saliva by reabsorbing water and electrolytes equally and secreting enzymes and mucins, resulting in isotonic saliva compared to plasma.

subTopics.title: Mechanism and Regulation of Saliva Secretion

quizzes.question: Saliva secretion is primarily under neural control, ensuring a rapid and adaptable response to various stimuli. Describe the principal neural control mechanism for saliva secretion, detailing the neurotransmitter involved, the specific receptor subtypes on salivary gland cells, and the intracellular signaling pathways activated to stimulate saliva production.
quizzes.goodAnswer: The primary neural control of saliva secretion is mediated by the parasympathetic nervous system, utilizing acetylcholine (ACh) as the neurotransmitter, which acts on muscarinic M3 receptors located on acinar and ductal cells, subsequently activating the phospholipase C (PLC) pathway, leading to increased intracellular calcium and stimulation of saliva secretion.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: The primary neural control of saliva secretion is mediated by the sympathetic nervous system, utilizing norepinephrine (NE) as the neurotransmitter, which acts on muscarinic M2 receptors located on acinar and ductal cells, subsequently activating the adenylyl cyclase (AC) pathway, leading to decreased intracellular calcium and inhibition of saliva secretion.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: The primary neural control of saliva secretion is mediated by the somatic nervous system, utilizing glutamate as the neurotransmitter, which acts on nicotinic receptors located on acinar and ductal cells, subsequently activating the Janus kinase (JAK) pathway, leading to altered intracellular sodium and stimulation of protein-rich saliva secretion.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: The primary neural control of saliva secretion is mediated by the parasympathetic nervous system, utilizing norepinephrine (NE) as the neurotransmitter, which acts on β-adrenergic receptors located on acinar and ductal cells, subsequently activating the protein kinase A (PKA) pathway, leading to increased intracellular cAMP and stimulation of enzyme-rich saliva secretion.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: The primary neural control of saliva secretion is mediated by the autonomic nervous system, utilizing dopamine as the neurotransmitter, which acts on dopaminergic receptors located on acinar and ductal cells, subsequently activating the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway, leading to modified intracellular potassium and stimulation of mucous-rich saliva secretion.

quizzes.question: While parasympathetic innervation is the primary driver of saliva secretion, the sympathetic nervous system also modulates salivary gland function. Explain the role of the sympathetic nervous system in regulating saliva secretion, including the neurotransmitter released, the adrenergic receptor subtypes involved, and the typical effects on saliva volume and composition in comparison to parasympathetic stimulation.
quizzes.goodAnswer: Sympathetic stimulation of salivary glands primarily involves the release of norepinephrine (NE), acting on β-adrenergic receptors, which leads to a smaller volume of viscous, protein-rich saliva, and also via α-adrenergic receptors inducing vasoconstriction, thereby reducing overall salivary flow, contrasting with the copious watery saliva from parasympathetic action.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Parasympathetic stimulation of salivary glands primarily involves the release of norepinephrine (NE), acting on α-adrenergic receptors, which leads to a larger volume of watery, enzyme-rich saliva, and also via β-adrenergic receptors inducing vasodilation, thereby increasing overall salivary flow, similar to typical sympathetic action.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Sympathetic stimulation of salivary glands primarily involves the release of acetylcholine (ACh), acting on muscarinic receptors, which leads to a larger volume of watery, enzyme-rich saliva, and also via nicotinic receptors inducing vasodilation, thereby increasing overall salivary flow, mimicking parasympathetic effects.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Sympathetic stimulation of salivary glands primarily involves the release of epinephrine (Epi), acting on muscarinic receptors, which leads to a smaller volume of serous, electrolyte-rich saliva, and also via α-adrenergic receptors inducing vasodilation, thereby increasing overall salivary flow, opposite to typical sympathetic effects.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Sympathetic stimulation of salivary glands primarily involves the release of dopamine (DA), acting on dopaminergic receptors, which leads to a larger volume of mucous, protein-poor saliva, and also via β-adrenergic receptors inducing vasoconstriction, thereby reducing overall salivary flow, resulting in a composition similar to parasympathetic saliva.

quizzes.question: The production of saliva is described by a two-stage model that involves distinct processes in acinar and ductal cells. Describe this two-stage model of saliva secretion, outlining the specific processes occurring in acinar cells during primary saliva formation and the subsequent modifications carried out by ductal cells to achieve the final saliva composition.
quizzes.goodAnswer: The two-stage model of saliva secretion begins with acinar cells producing an isotonic primary saliva resembling plasma through active transport of ions and water, followed by ductal cells modifying this primary secretion by reabsorbing sodium chloride (NaCl) and secreting potassium (K+) and bicarbonate (HCO3-) ions, resulting in a hypotonic final saliva.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: The two-stage model of saliva secretion begins with ductal cells producing a hypertonic primary saliva resembling interstitial fluid through passive diffusion of ions and water, followed by acinar cells modifying this primary secretion by reabsorbing potassium chloride (KCl) and secreting sodium (Na+) and phosphate (PO43-) ions, resulting in an isotonic final saliva.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: The two-stage model of saliva secretion begins with acinar cells producing a hypertonic primary saliva with high protein content through facilitated diffusion of ions and water, followed by ductal cells modifying this primary secretion by secreting sodium chloride (NaCl) and reabsorbing potassium (K+) and bicarbonate (HCO3-) ions, resulting in a hypertonic final saliva.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: The two-stage model of saliva secretion begins with acinar cells producing a hypotonic primary saliva with low electrolyte content through active transport of water only, followed by ductal cells modifying this primary secretion by secreting water and reabsorbing sodium chloride (NaCl), potassium (K+) and bicarbonate (HCO3-) ions, resulting in an isotonic final saliva.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: The two-stage model of saliva secretion begins with ductal cells producing an isotonic primary saliva resembling lymph through active transport of proteins and lipids, followed by acinar cells modifying this primary secretion by reabsorbing water and secreting sodium chloride (NaCl), potassium (K+) and bicarbonate (HCO3-) ions, resulting in a hypotonic final saliva.

quizzes.question: Saliva is a complex fluid containing both inorganic and organic components that contribute to oral health. Identify the major inorganic components of saliva and describe their specific physiological roles in maintaining oral homeostasis, including buffering capacity, enamel remineralization, and antimicrobial actions.
quizzes.goodAnswer: The major inorganic components of saliva include bicarbonate and phosphate ions, which provide crucial buffering capacity against dietary acids; calcium and phosphate ions, which promote enamel remineralization and maintain tooth integrity; and thiocyanate ions, which exhibit antimicrobial properties by inhibiting bacterial metabolism.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: The major inorganic components of saliva include sodium and potassium ions, which provide crucial buffering capacity against metabolic acids; calcium and fluoride ions, which promote enamel demineralization and increase tooth porosity; and chloride ions, which exhibit pro-inflammatory properties by activating immune responses.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: The major organic components of saliva include bicarbonate and sulfate ions, which provide crucial buffering capacity against gastric acids; magnesium and phosphate ions, which promote enamel remineralization and enhance dentin sensitivity; and iodide ions, which exhibit antiviral properties by interfering with viral replication.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: The major inorganic components of saliva include chloride and fluoride ions, which provide crucial buffering capacity against bacterial acids; sodium and potassium ions, which promote enamel demineralization and reduce tooth hardness; and bromide ions, which exhibit antifungal properties by disrupting fungal cell walls.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: The major organic components of saliva include sodium and chloride ions, which provide crucial buffering capacity against environmental acids; calcium and magnesium ions, which promote enamel demineralization and increase tooth permeability; and thiocyanate enzymes, which exhibit pro-oxidant properties by generating reactive oxygen species.

quizzes.question: Saliva's organic components are essential for various functions within the oral cavity, ranging from digestion to immune defense. Describe the key organic components of saliva, such as α-amylase, mucins, lysozyme, and secretory IgA (sIgA), and explain their respective functional roles in facilitating digestion, lubrication, antimicrobial defense, and immunological protection.
quizzes.goodAnswer: Key organic components of saliva include α-amylase, which initiates starch digestion in the oral cavity; mucins, which provide lubrication and protection to the oral mucosa; lysozyme, which exhibits antimicrobial activity by hydrolyzing bacterial cell walls; and secretory IgA (sIgA), which provides immunological defense by neutralizing pathogens and preventing microbial adhesion.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Key inorganic components of saliva include α-amylase, which initiates protein digestion in the oral cavity; mucins, which provide structural support to the dental enamel; lysozyme, which exhibits antiviral activity by inhibiting viral replication; and secretory IgG (sIgG), which provides immunological defense by activating complement pathways and inducing inflammation.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Key organic components of saliva include lipase, which initiates lipid digestion in the oral cavity; collagen, which provides lubrication and protection to the gingival tissues; peroxidase, which exhibits antioxidant activity by scavenging free radicals; and secretory IgE (sIgE), which provides immunological defense by mediating allergic reactions and promoting vasodilation.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Key organic components of saliva include α-glucosidase, which initiates sucrose digestion in the oral cavity; elastin, which provides elasticity and recoil to the oral mucosa; catalase, which exhibits antibacterial activity by oxidizing bacterial toxins; and secretory IgM (sIgM), which provides immunological defense by agglutinating pathogens and activating the classical complement pathway.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Key inorganic components of saliva include α-amylase, which initiates starch digestion in the stomach; mucins, which provide lubrication and protection to the esophageal mucosa; peroxidase, which exhibits antimicrobial activity by generating reactive oxygen species; and secretory IgD (sIgD), which provides immunological defense by acting as a B-cell receptor and regulating lymphocyte differentiation.

quizzes.question: Proline-rich proteins (PRPs) are a significant group of organic components in saliva with diverse functions. Explain the multifaceted roles of proline-rich proteins (PRPs) in saliva, focusing on their interaction with tannins, their contribution to calcium homeostasis and enamel integrity, and their potential involvement in antimicrobial activities within the oral environment.
quizzes.goodAnswer: Proline-rich proteins (PRPs) in saliva function by binding tannins, reducing their astringency and toxicity; contributing to calcium binding, thereby aiding in enamel protection and remineralization processes; and exhibiting antimicrobial functions against certain oral bacteria, thus contributing to oral health.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Histidine-rich proteins (HRPs) in saliva function by binding lipids, enhancing their digestion and absorption; contributing to phosphate binding, thereby aiding in enamel demineralization and increasing tooth sensitivity; and exhibiting pro-inflammatory functions, thus contributing to periodontal inflammation.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Cysteine-rich proteins (CRPs) in saliva function by binding sugars, enhancing taste perception and appetite; contributing to potassium binding, thereby aiding in dentin protection and reducing enamel porosity; and exhibiting antiviral functions against certain oral viruses, thus contributing to viral clearance.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Glycine-rich proteins (GRPs) in saliva function by binding starches, facilitating carbohydrate digestion and absorption; contributing to sodium binding, thereby aiding in dentin demineralization and increasing enamel permeability; and exhibiting antifungal functions against certain oral fungi, thus contributing to fungal overgrowth.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Lysine-rich proteins (LRPs) in saliva function by binding minerals, enhancing mineral absorption and utilization; contributing to magnesium binding, thereby aiding in cementum protection and reducing root resorption; and exhibiting antioxidant functions, thus contributing to oxidative stress reduction but not direct antimicrobial activity.
